Posts.Content: Aug 21, 2008 09:24AM pinoideae wrote: I was so darn fatigued for years (after bc treatments), gained weight.   My cholesterol had skyrocketed as well.  Exercised for 2 years, it helped some for cholesterol and weight, but definitely not the fatigue.  The day I first took synthroid, I immediately felt energy.  I felt lighter, like something was pushing down on my shoulders before but was lifted (although I had no idea of something pushing down on my shoulders prior to synthroid).  Cholesterol is now normal.  My weight is normal, well maybe I could lose 10 lbs, but I dont have to go to the gym anymore to struggle to maintain my weight.    There is more than one test for thyroid, here is a link: http://www.stillpointhealth.com/LowThyroidDilemma.html You should get to the bottom of your fatigue.  If it isn't thyroid, then it could be something else. Good luck to you! Whoopsiedoodles, so sorry to hear you are dealing with ms now.
Posts.Title: Still have the fatigue after 2 years. Mary-Lou Molly2013

Posts.Content: Oct 19, 2008 10:48PM pinoideae wrote: Here is her latest update: October 14 We have about 6 inches of snow on the ground and it feels like it means to stick around!  The girls are playing in the pep band for a bunch of volley-ball games tonight, or I'm sure they would be out on the trails with head-lamps in the dark Chemo went kind of "normal" yesterday.  I got there on time, but my port in my chest refused to work and give blood.  After trying for about 20 minutes my nurse Kim ordered a drug called "Cath-flow" (I think that's the name.....)  They put some in the port and leave it alone for a few minutes to let it unclog the port.  While that did its job, Dr Kelley did the chemo in my brain.  The pressure in my head is fine and the infusion went fine.  Once again, even though I got strong anti-nausea drugs before the chemo, I still managed to throw up!   Grrrrrr.....that just wears me out.  At least we know which chemo makes me sick since I hadn't had the other one yet.  About an hour later they got my blood numbers and it was fine for me to get my last chemo.  By the time that one was done I was feeling mostly just fine....didn't want anything to eat, but didn't feel sick anymore. It is colder than I would like it to be, so I think I will start a little fire in the fireplace and have some tea.
Posts.Title: Alaska Deb Update newter OrliNaaman

Posts.Content: Aug 14, 2008 12:33PM pinoideae wrote: Limitations The one drawback of radiation therapy noted by the EBCTCG meta-analysis was an increase in the incidence of secondary cancers (new cancers unrelated to the original breast cancer) and in mortality from heart disease and lung cancer. However, the investigators emphasize that modern radiation therapy technology now minimizes the radiation doses to the heart, lungs, and other breast, compared to the doses given at the time these trials were conducted. Comments "These long awaited results from the EBCTCG overview analysis demonstrate an important effect for adjuvant radiation therapy in the treatment of primary breast cancer," says Abrams, noting that the survival benefit is apparent both in women who undergo breast-conserving surgery and those with cancer in their lymph nodes who undergo a mastectomy. The authors place their results in the context of combination therapy, and state that "the moderate differences in 15-year breast cancer mortality produced by better local control can be combined with the moderate differences produced by chemotherapy and hormonal therapy...yielding in total quite substantial effects on 15-year breast cancer mortality."
Posts.Title: RADIATION INCREASES SURVIVABILITY OF HIGH RISK PATIENTS. worriedhubby MarieKelly

Posts.Content: Sep 11, 2008 12:08AM pinoideae wrote: Had reduction on radiation side and good side.  Piece of cake for me compared to the pedicle tram I had in June (however all is well now).  You will wake up with drains, and will have lifting restrictions, and must watch for any signs of infections.  Some doctors like to put their patients on antibiotics during surgery and after surgery for about a week. Make sure you do not touch your incisions without washing and change your dressing every day or every other day.  Hospital carry staph infections.  This is not in your control if you get a staph infection in hospital.  You must be vigilant to look for infection however.  I have never had it, but there are ladies on this board, that might tell you what to look for that have had it.  If you see puss then go to emergency or see your doctor immediately.  Hopefully, your tissue will be sent to pathology as well.
Posts.Title: Breast reduction with lumpectomy Wndalina Wndalina

Posts.Content: Jul 27, 2008 09:29PM pinoideae wrote: I think it depends on the type of tumor a breast cancer patient may have.  Triple negative tumors tend to be fast growing tumors, and are likely never to have been there for years.

Posts.Content: Jan 13, 2009 08:04AM pinoideae wrote: For those of  you who may wonder about the long-term effects of radiation treatment (I know I have from time to time, read this). Longtime breast cancer survivor shares words of encouragement St. Petersburg, Florida -- 22-year-old Betty married her sweetheart, Frank Biscotto, back in 1954. "Little did I know at that time what was ahead for me," said Betty as she flipped through her wedding photos. Almost four months later, their lives changed forever. "I just usually sleep on my side and this particular night, when I turned over, I had such a sharp pain in my breast. So, I turned on my back and started to feel around and lo and behold there was a lump," said Betty. Within weeks, Betty had a radical mastectomy, radiation, and lymph nodes removed. This happened at a time when no one even talked about breast cancer or reconstructive surgery. When asked if she knew anyone else with breast cancer back then, Betty replied, "No, not at that time. Not at all." But that didn't stop Betty from going to the beach and enjoying her life. She lives everyday to its fullest. "We were determined that we were going to make it through. We prayed a lot." Now the 76-year-old offers words of wisdom to others. "Your attitude has to be a positive attitude. That you're not going to let cancer take over your life. That you're going to beat it." Betty credits faith, hope, a positive attitude, and support from someone who made sure she wasn't alone in this battle. Betty pauses as she stares at her wedding photos of Frank. "At that time, I didn't realize how special [Frank was] but, as time went on, he turned out to be extra, extra special," she said. "Frank is my life. He's been my support 100 percent of the time... always there when I need him." After 55 years of marriage, Frank is still right by her side. He takes a moment to make a toast in honor of his wife. "Here's to many more years together, Betty, and good health! Thank you Lord for all your blessings." Betty says she is the perfect example of how early detection can save lives. She encourages people to pay attention to any changes in their bodies, to do your monthly breast self-exam and to schedule your annual mammograms.
